# APPENDIX
## Appendix A. Proof of Theorem 1

Let $f^{*} \in \arg \min _{f \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(f\left(x_{t}\right)\right)$. We define the function

$$
\hat{f}^{*}=\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right) \mathbb{1}_{\mathcal{X}_{n}}
$$

where $T_{n}=\left\{1 \leqslant t \leqslant T: x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}\right\}, x_{n}$ the center of hyper region $\mathcal{X}_{n}$ (i.e. for any $x \in$ $\left.\mathcal{X}_{n},\left\|x-x_{n}\right\| \leqslant 2^{-1}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|\right)$. The proof starts with the following regret decomposition

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right)=\underbrace{\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)}_{R_{1}}+\underbrace{\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)}_{R_{2}}
$$

We will refer to $R_{1}$ as the estimation error, which consists of the error incurred by sequentially learning the best Chaining-Tree $\hat{f}^{*} . R_{2}$ will refer to the approximation error, which involves approximating Hölder functions in $\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)$ by piecewise-constant functions with $|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|$ pieces.

Step 1: Upper-bounding the approximation error $R_{2}$. Note that by definition of the ChainingTree $\mathcal{T}$ (see Definition 1), $\left\{\mathcal{X}_{n}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})\right\}$ forms a partition of $\mathcal{X}=\mathcal{X}_{\text {root }(\mathcal{T})}$ and for any leaf $n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$

$$
\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|=\frac{\left|\mathcal{X}_{\text {root }(\mathcal{T})}\right|}{2^{\mathrm{d}(n)-1}}=\frac{|\mathcal{X}|}{2^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})-1}}
$$

Then,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{2} & =\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \\
& \leqslant \sum_{t=1}^{T} G\left|\hat{f}^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)-f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right| \quad \leftarrow \ell_{t} \text { is } G \text {-Lipschitz } \\
& =G \sum_{t=1}^{T}\left|\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}-f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right| \quad \leftarrow \text { by (12) } \\
& =G \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left|f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right)-f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right| \quad \leftarrow\left\{\mathcal{X}_{n}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})\right\} \text { partitions } \mathcal{X} \\
& \leqslant G \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}} L\left\|x_{n}-x_{t}\right\|_{\infty}^{\alpha} \quad \leftarrow f^{*} \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L) \\
& \leqslant G \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L 2^{-\alpha}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\left|T_{n}\right| \quad \leftarrow x_{n} \text { center of } \mathcal{X}_{n} \\
& \leqslant G L 2^{-\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} T
\end{aligned}
$$

where the last inequality is by (14) and because the leaves form a partition of $\mathcal{X}$, which implies $\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left|T_{n}\right|=T$.

Step 2: Upper-bounding the estimation error $R_{1}$. We now turn to the bound of the estimation error, that is the regret with respect to best Chaining-Tree $\hat{f}^{*}$.
Step 2.1: Parametrization of $\hat{f}^{*}$ in terms of $\theta_{n}$. Note that the parametrization of $\hat{f}^{*}$ in terms of $\theta_{n}$ is non-unique. We design below a parametrization such that for any $x \in \mathcal{X}$

$$
\hat{f}^{*}(x)=\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}
$$

and which will allow us to leverage the chaining structure of our Chaining-Tree. We define,

$$
\theta_{\operatorname{root}(\mathcal{T})}=f^{*}\left(x_{\operatorname{root}(\mathcal{T})}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \theta_{n}=f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right)-f^{*}\left(x_{\mathrm{p}(n)}\right), \quad \text { for } n \neq \operatorname{root}(\mathcal{T})
$$

where $T_{n}=\left\{1 \leqslant t \leqslant T: x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}\right\}$ and $x_{n}$ stands for the center of subregion $\mathcal{X}_{n}$ for any $n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})$.
Let us show that the above construction (17) indeed satisfies (16). To do so, we fix $x \in \mathcal{X}$ and proceed by induction on $m=1, \ldots, \mathrm{~d}(\mathcal{T})$, by proving that

$$
\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n) \leqslant m}=\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n)=m}
$$

First, note that $\left(\mathcal{H}_{1}\right)$ is true by definition of $\theta_{\operatorname{root}(\mathcal{T})}$. Then, let $m \geqslant 1$, and assume that $\left(\mathcal{H}_{m}\right)$ is satisfied, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n) \leqslant m+1} \\
& =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n) \leqslant m}+\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n)=m+1} \\
& =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n)=m}+\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n)=m+1} \quad \leftarrow \text { by }\left(\mathcal{H}_{m}\right) \\
& =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n)=m} \\
& \quad+\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right)-f^{*}\left(x_{\mathrm{p}(n)}\right)\right) \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n)=m+1} \quad \leftarrow \text { by } \\
& =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \mathbb{1}_{\mathrm{d}(n)=m+1},
\end{aligned}
$$

which concludes the induction. In particular, for $m=\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T}),\left(\mathcal{H}_{m}\right)$ yields

$$
\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}=\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}=\hat{f}^{*}(x)
$$

where the last equality is by definition of $\hat{f}^{*}$ in (12).
Step 2.2: Upper-bounding $\left|\theta_{n}\right|$. The key advantage of the parametrization $\theta_{n}$ in (17) is that it leverages the chaining structure of our tree. Each node aims to correct the error made by its parent, and as we show below, this error decreases significantly with the depth $\mathrm{d}(n)$ of the node $n$. Let $n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T}) \backslash\{\operatorname{root}(\mathcal{T})\}$

$$
\left|\theta_{n}\right|=\left|f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right)-f^{*}\left(x_{\mathrm{p}(n)}\right)\right| \leqslant L\left\|x_{n}-x_{\mathrm{p}(n)}\right\|_{\infty}^{\alpha}=L 2^{-\alpha}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}=L|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} 2^{-\alpha \mathrm{d}(n)}
$$

where the last equalities are because $\mathcal{X}_{n} \subset \mathcal{X}_{\mathrm{p}(n)}$ and $\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|=|\mathcal{X}| 2^{-(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}$, from Definition 1. Furthermore, by definition of $\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L),\left|f^{*}(x)\right| \leqslant B$ for any $x \in \mathcal{X}$, hence

$$
\left|\theta_{\operatorname{root}(\mathcal{T})}\right|=\left|f^{*}\left(x_{\operatorname{root}(\mathcal{T})}\right)\right| \leqslant B
$$

Step 2.3: Proof of the regret upper bound. We are now ready to upper bound the estimation error in (13). We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1} & =\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \\
& =\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n, t} \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}\right)-\ell_{t}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} \theta_{n} \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}\right) \\
& \leqslant \sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})} g_{n, t}\left(\theta_{n, t}-\theta_{n}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

by convexity of $\ell_{t}$, where $g_{n, t}$ is the partial subgradient in $\theta_{n, t}$ as defined in Equation (4). Now, from Assumption 1 on the grad-step procedure to optimize $\theta_{n, t}$ and with $\theta_{n, 1}=0, g_{n, t} \leqslant G \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}$, we further have, with $T_{n}=\left\{1 \leqslant t \leqslant T: g_{n, t} \neq 0\right\}$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1} & \leqslant G \sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{T})}\left|\theta_{n}\right|\left(C_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|}+C_{2}\right) \\
& =G \sum_{m=1}^{d(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{n: \mathrm{d}(n)=m}\left|\theta_{n}\right|\left(C_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|}+C_{2}\right) \\
& \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{n: \mathrm{d}(n)=m}\left(C_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|}+C_{2}\right) 2^{-\alpha m}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now, because in a $d$-regular decision tree, the number of nodes with depth $m$ equals $|\{n: \mathrm{d}(n)=$ $m\}|=2^{d(m-1)}$ (recall that the depth of the root is 1 ), and because $\left\{\mathcal{X}_{n}: \mathrm{d}(n)=m\right\}$ forms a partition of $\mathcal{X}$, we have $\sum_{n: \mathrm{d}(n)=m} T_{n}=T$ and by Cauchy-Schwarz inequality

$$
\sum_{n: \mathrm{d}(n)=m} \sqrt{T_{n}} \leqslant \sqrt{2^{d(m-1)} \sum_{n: \mathrm{d}(n)=m} T_{n}}=\sqrt{2^{d(m-1)} T}
$$

which substituted into the previous upper bound entails

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1} & \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}\left(C_{1} 2^{\frac{d(m-1)}{2}-\alpha m} \sqrt{T}+C_{2} 2^{d(m-1)-\alpha m}\right) \\
& =B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(2^{-\frac{d}{2}} C_{1} \sqrt{T} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right)}+2^{-d} C_{2} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m(d-\alpha)}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Step 3: Conclusion and optimization of $\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})$. To conclude the proof, we consider three cases according to the sign of $d-2 \alpha$ :

- Case 1: if $d<2 \alpha$. Then
$2^{-\frac{d}{2}} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right)} \leqslant \frac{1}{1-2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}} \quad$ and $\quad 2^{-d} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m(d-\alpha)} \leqslant 2^{-d} \sum_{m=0}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m \alpha} \leqslant 2^{-d} \frac{2^{\alpha(d(\mathcal{T})+1)}}{2^{\alpha}-1} \stackrel{(2 \alpha \geqslant 1)}{\leqslant} 2^{\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}$,
and (21) yields

$$
R_{1} \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(\frac{C_{1} \sqrt{T}}{1-2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}}+C_{2} 2^{\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}\right)
$$

Therefore, combining with (13) and (15), the regret is upper-bounded as

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right) \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(\frac{C_{1} \sqrt{T}}{1-2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}}+C_{2} 2^{\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}+T 2^{-\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}\right)
$$

The choice $\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})=\frac{1}{d} \log _{2} T$ entails

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right) \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(\frac{C_{1}}{1-2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}}+4 C_{2}+1\right) \sqrt{T}
$$

- Case 2: if $d=2 \alpha$. Then

$$
2^{-\frac{d}{2}} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right)} \leqslant \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T}) \quad \text { and } \quad 2^{-d} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m(d-\alpha)}=2^{-d} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m \alpha} \leqslant 2^{\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}
$$

and (21) yields

$$
R_{1} \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T} \mathrm{~d}(\mathcal{T})+C_{2} 2^{\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}\right)
$$

Therefore, combining with (13) and (15), the regret is upper-bounded as
$\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right) \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+2^{\alpha} L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T} \mathrm{~d}(\mathcal{T})+C_{2} 2^{\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}+T 2^{-\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}\right)$.
The choice $\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})=\frac{1}{d} \log _{2} T$ entails

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right) \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+2^{\alpha} L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(\frac{C_{1}}{d} \log _{2} T+4 C_{2}+1\right) \sqrt{T}
$$

- Case 3: if $d>2 \alpha$. Then

$$
2^{-\frac{d}{2}} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right)} \leqslant \frac{2^{\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right) \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}}{2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}-1} \quad \text { and } \quad 2^{-d} \sum_{m=2}^{\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})} 2^{m(d-\alpha)} \leqslant \frac{2^{(d-\alpha) \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}}{2^{d-\alpha}-1} \leqslant 2^{(d-\alpha) \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}
$$

where the last inequality is because $\left(2^{d-\alpha}-1\right)^{-1} \leqslant\left(2^{d / 2}-1\right)^{-1} \leqslant(\sqrt{2}-1)^{-1} \leqslant 4$. And (21) yields

$$
R_{1} \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T} \frac{2^{\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right) \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}}{2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}-1}+C_{2} 2^{(d-\alpha) \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}\right)
$$

Therefore, combining with (13) and (15), the regret is upper-bounded as
$\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right) \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T} \frac{2^{\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right) \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}}{2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}-1}+C_{2} 2^{(d-\alpha) \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})+2}+T 2^{-\alpha \mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})}\right)$.
The choice $\mathrm{d}(\mathcal{T})=\frac{1}{d} \log _{2} T$ entails

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right) \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+L G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\left(\frac{C_{1}}{2^{\frac{d}{2}-\alpha}-1}+4 C_{2}+1\right) T^{1-\frac{\alpha}{d}}
$$

Conclusion. Combining the three cases (22), (23), and (24) concludes the proof of the regret bound, which we summarize below
$\operatorname{Reg}_{T}\left(\mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)\right) \leqslant B G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{T}+C_{2}\right)+G L|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \begin{cases}\left(\Phi\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right) C_{1}+4 C_{2}+1\right) \sqrt{T} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\ \left(\frac{C_{1}}{d} \log _{2} T+4 C_{2}+1\right) \sqrt{T} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\ \left(\Phi\left(\frac{d}{2}-\alpha\right) C_{1}+4 C_{2}+1\right) T^{1-\frac{\alpha}{d}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha\end{cases}$
where $\Phi(u)=\left|2^{u}-1\right|^{-1}$.

# Appendix B. Proof of Theorem 2 

We state here the full version of Theorem 2 that we prove right after.
Theorem 3 Let $T, d \geqslant 1$ and $\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}, \bar{\mathcal{X}}, \overline{\mathcal{W}}\right)$ be a core regular tree with $C T\left\{\mathcal{T}_{n, k},(n, k) \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right) \times\right.$ $[K]\}$ satisfying the same assumptions as in Theorem 1 and root nodes initialized as $\theta_{\text {root }\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k}\right), 1}=$ $\gamma_{k} \in \Gamma$, for all $(n, k) \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right) \times[K]$. Then, Algorithm 2 with a weight subroutine as in Assumption 2, achieves the regret upper-bound with respect to any $f \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L), L>0$,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant \inf _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)}\left\{\beta_{1} \sqrt{T|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|}+\beta_{2}|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|\right. \\
& +G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\
\psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\
\psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{2}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha,
\end{array}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\beta_{1}=2 C_{3} G \sqrt{\log \left(2 B T\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)}$ and $\beta_{2}=G\left(2^{-1} C_{1}+C_{2} 2^{-1} T^{-\frac{1}{2}}+C_{4}\right)$, local Lipschitz constants $L_{n}(f) \leqslant L$ as in (7), $\psi_{1}=\Phi(d / 2-\alpha) C_{1}+4 C_{2}+1, \psi_{2}=C_{1} / d+4 C_{2}+1$, and $\Phi, C_{1}, C_{2}$ as in Theorem 1.
Moreover, if $\ell_{1}, \ldots, \ell_{T}$ are $\eta$-exp-concave with some $\eta>0$, one has:
$\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant \inf _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)}\left\{\beta_{3}|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\ \psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\ \psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{2}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha,\end{array}\right\}\right.$
with $\beta_{3}=\frac{C_{3}^{2} \log \left(2 B T\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)}{2 \mu}+C_{4} G+2^{-1} G\left(C_{1}+C_{2} T^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right)$ and $0<\mu \leqslant \min \{1 / G, \eta\}$.
Proof [of Theorem 3] Let $L>0, \alpha \in(0,1], f^{*} \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)$ and $\varepsilon>0$ be the precision of the grid $\Gamma, K=\lfloor 2 B / \varepsilon\rfloor$ the number of experts in each node in $\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$. Let $\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$ be some pruned tree from $\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}, \bar{\mathcal{X}}, \overline{\mathcal{W}}\right)$ with prediction functions $\overline{\mathcal{W}}=\left\{\left(\hat{f}_{n, k}\right)_{k \in[K]}, n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right\}$ on subsets $\overline{\mathcal{X}}=\left\{\mathcal{X}_{n}, n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right\}$. We call $\hat{f}_{\mathcal{T}}$ the associated prediction function of pruning $\mathcal{T}$ (see Definition 2) such that at any time $t \geqslant 1$,

$$
\hat{f}_{\mathcal{T}, t}(x)=\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \hat{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}(x), \quad x \in \mathcal{X}
$$

with $k_{n}=\arg \min _{k \in[K]}\left|(-B+(k-1) \varepsilon)-f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right)\right|$ the best approximating constant of $f^{*}\left(x_{n}\right)$ where $x_{n} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}$ is the center of the sub-region $\mathcal{X}_{n}$, i.e. for any $x \in \mathcal{X}_{n},\left\|x-x_{n}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant 2^{-1}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|$. We have a decomposition of regret as:

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f)=\underbrace{\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{\mathcal{T}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)}_{=: R_{1}}+\underbrace{\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{\mathcal{T}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)}_{=: R_{2}}
$$

$R_{1}$ is the regret related to the estimation error of the core expert tree $\mathcal{T}_{0}$ compared to some pruning $\mathcal{T}$ from it. On the other hand, $R_{2}$ is related to the error of the pruning tree $\mathcal{T}$ against some function $f^{*}$.

Step 1: Upper-bounding $R_{2}$ as local chaining tree regrets. Recall that according to Definition 2, pruning subsets $\left\{\mathcal{X}_{n}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})\right\}$ form a partition of $\mathcal{X}=\mathcal{X}_{\text {root }\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)}$. Hence, for any $x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}$, prediction from pruning $\mathcal{T}$ at time $t$ is $\hat{f}_{\mathcal{T}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)=\hat{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)$ with $n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$ the unique leaf such that $x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}$ at time $t$. Then, $R_{2}$ can be written as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{2} & =\sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{\mathcal{T}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \\
& =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \\
& \leqslant \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}} \ell_{t}\left(\tilde{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where we set $T_{n}=\left\{1 \leqslant t \leqslant T: x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}\right\}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$ and (26) is because $\hat{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}=\left[\tilde{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}\right]_{B} \leqslant$ $\tilde{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}$ and $\ell_{t}$ is convex and has minimum in $[-B, B]$.
The decomposition in (26) represents a sum of local error approximations of the function $f^{*}$ over the partition $\left\{\mathcal{X}_{n}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})\right\}$, using predictors $\tilde{f}_{n, k_{n}}$ located at the leaves of the pruned tree $\mathcal{T}$. Recall that for every $n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right), \tilde{f}_{n, k_{n}}$ is a prediction function associated with a CT $\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}$, where the root node starts from $\theta_{\text {root }\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right), 1}=-B+\left(k_{n}-1\right) \varepsilon \in \Gamma$ on $\mathcal{X}_{n}$. In proof of Theorem 1 (Appendix A) we study a regret bound (13) decomposed into two terms: estimation and approximation. In particular, we showed that any CT adapts to any regularity $(L, \alpha) \in \mathbb{R}_{+} \times(0,1]$ of $f^{*}$. Thus, the approximation error of CT $\tilde{f}_{n, k_{n}}$ with respect to $f^{*}$ remains similar to that in (15), but now with regard to an Hölder function with a constant $L_{n}\left(f^{*}\right) \geqslant 0$ over $\mathcal{X}_{n}$. Specifically, from (26), we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R_{2} \leqslant \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}[\underbrace{\left.\left[\underbrace{\left.\mathcal{C}_{n, k_{n}}\right)}_{m=1} \sum_{n^{\prime}: d\left(n^{\prime}\right)=m} \right\rvert\, \theta_{n^{\prime}}-\theta_{n^{\prime}, 1} \mid\right)\left(C_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n^{\prime}}\right|}+C_{2}\right)}_{\text {estimation error as in (20) }}] \\
& \text { with } C_{1}, C_{2} \text { as in Assumption 1 and where we set in (17), } \\
& \theta_{\text {root }\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right)}=f^{*}\left(x_{\text {root }\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right)}\right) \quad \text { and } \quad \theta_{n^{\prime}}=f^{*}\left(x_{n^{\prime}}\right)-f^{*}\left(x_{\mathrm{p}\left(n^{\prime}\right)}\right), \quad n^{\prime} \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right) \backslash\left\{\operatorname{root}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right)\right\} .
\end{aligned}
$$

In particular, we have for $n^{\prime}=\operatorname{root}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right)$,

$$
\left|\theta_{n^{\prime}}-\theta_{n^{\prime}, 1}\right|=\left|f^{*}\left(x_{\operatorname{root}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right)}\right)-\left(-B+\left(k_{n}-1\right)\right) \varepsilon\right| \leqslant \frac{\varepsilon}{2}
$$

by definition of $k_{n}$ and since $\Gamma=\{-B+(k-1) \varepsilon\}_{k \in[K]}$ is an $\varepsilon$-discretization of the $y$-axis. Moreover, if $n^{\prime} \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right), \mathrm{d}\left(n^{\prime}\right) \geqslant 2$, one has $\theta_{n^{\prime}, 1}=0$ and

$$
\left|\theta_{n^{\prime}}-\theta_{n^{\prime}, 1}\right|=\left|\theta_{n^{\prime}}\right| \leqslant L_{n}\left(f^{*}\right)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha} 2^{-\alpha \mathrm{d}\left(n^{\prime}\right)}
$$

according to (18) with $f^{*} \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}\left(\mathcal{X}_{n}, L_{n}\right)$.
Then, following the same optimization steps as for Theorem 1, in each $\mathrm{d}\left(\mathcal{T}_{n, k_{n}}\right), n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$ of (27), we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R_{2} \leqslant G \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \frac{\varepsilon}{2}\left(C_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|}+C_{2}\right) \\
& +G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}\left(f^{*}\right) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\
\psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\
\psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{d}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\psi_{1}=\Phi(d / 2-\alpha) C_{1}+4 C_{2}+1, \psi_{2}=C_{1} / d+4 C_{2}+1$, and $\Phi$ defined in Theorem 1. Cauchy-Schwarz inequality gives

$$
\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(C_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|}+C_{2}\right) \leqslant C_{1} \sqrt{|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})| T}+C_{2}|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|
$$

Finally,

$$
\begin{aligned}
& R_{2} \leqslant \frac{\varepsilon}{2} G\left(C_{1} \sqrt{|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})| T}+C_{2}|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|\right) \\
& +G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}\left(f^{*}\right) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\
\psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\
\psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{d}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Step 2: Upper-bounding the pruning estimation error $R_{1}$. We aim at bounding the estimation error $R_{1}$ due to the error incurred by sequentially learning the best pruned tree prediction and the best root node in $\Gamma$ inside each pruned leaves. Note that at each time $t$, only a subset of nodes of $\mathcal{T}_{0}$ are active and output predictions: for any time $t \geqslant 1$, let us denote $\mathcal{N}_{t} \subset \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$ the set of active nodes (i.e. making a prediction) at time $t$. Remark that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right) & =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)} \sum_{k=1}^{K} w_{n, k, t} \hat{f}_{n, k, t}\left(x_{t}\right) \\
& =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n, k, t} \hat{f}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)+\sum_{n \notin \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n, k, t} \hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

by definition of $\hat{f}_{t}$ and the so called trick of prediction with sleeping experts, e.g. in Gaillard et al. (2014). Recall that $\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}=\nabla_{\tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t}} \ell_{t}\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n, k, t} \hat{f}_{n, k, t}\left(x_{t}\right)+\sum_{n \notin \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n, k, t} \hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \in$ $\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)| \times K}$, for all $t \geqslant 1$. Then, for all $n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right), k \in[K]$,

$$
\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}= \begin{cases}\ell_{t}^{\prime}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \hat{f}_{n, k, t}\left(x_{t}\right) & \text { if } n \in \mathcal{N}_{t} \\ \ell_{t}^{\prime}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right) & \text { if } n \notin \mathcal{N}_{t}\end{cases}
$$

For any $t \geqslant 1, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$ and $k \in[K]$, one has:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t} & =\sum_{n^{\prime} \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)} \sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K} w_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t} \tilde{g}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t} \\
& =\ell_{t}^{\prime}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \underbrace{\sum_{n^{\prime} \in \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K} w_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t} \hat{f}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)}_{=\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t} \\
& =\ell_{t}^{\prime}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)\left(\sum_{n^{\prime} \in \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t} \hat{f}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)+\sum_{n^{\prime} \notin \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t} \hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t} \\
& =\ell_{t}^{\prime}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \\
& \times \begin{cases}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)-\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \text { if } n \notin \mathcal{N}_{t}, \\
\left(\sum_{n^{\prime} \in \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t} \hat{f}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)+\sum_{n^{\prime} \notin \mathcal{N}_{t}} \sum_{k^{\prime}=1}^{K} \tilde{w}_{n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}, t} \hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)-\hat{f}_{n, k, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \text { else } \\
= \begin{cases}0 & \text { if } n \notin \mathcal{N}_{t} \\
\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t} & \text { else },\end{cases} \\
=\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}},
\end{aligned}
$$

where the second equality follows from (31), the third from (32), and the fourth from (33). Finally, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{n, k, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} & \leqslant \ell_{t}^{\prime}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)-\hat{f}_{n, k, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \leftarrow \text { by convexity of } \ell_{t} \\
& =\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \\
& =\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t} \quad \leftarrow \text { by (34) }
\end{aligned}
$$

and setting $T_{n}=\left\{1 \leqslant t \leqslant T: x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}\right\}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1}= & \sum_{t=1}^{T} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{n, k_{n}, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}}\right. & \leftarrow\left\{\mathcal{X}_{n}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})\right\} \text { partition of } \mathcal{X} \\
\leqslant & \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k_{n}, t}\right) & \leftarrow \text { by (35) } \\
\leqslant & \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(C_{3} \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)} \sqrt{\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k_{n}, t}\right)^{2}+C_{4} G}\right) \leftarrow \text { by Assumption } 2 \\
= & C_{4} G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+C_{3} \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sqrt{\sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k_{n}, t}\right)^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where last equality holds because for any $n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T}), \tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k_{n}, t}=0$ if $x_{t} \notin \mathcal{X}_{n}$.

- Case 1: $\left(\ell_{t}\right)_{1 \leqslant t \leqslant T}$ convex.

Since $\left\|\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant G,\left\|\mathbf{w}_{t}\right\|_{\infty} \leqslant 1, t \in[T]$ by Assumption 2 and using Cauchy-Schwartz inequality we get from Equation (36):

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1} & \leqslant C_{4} G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+2 C_{3} \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)} G \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} \\
& \leqslant C_{4} G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+2 C_{3} G \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})| \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left|T_{n}\right|} \\
& =C_{4} G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+2 C_{3} G \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})| T}
\end{aligned}
$$

In case of convex losses, we finally have by (25), (30) and (37) :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant 2 C_{3} G \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})| T}+\left(C_{2} \frac{\varepsilon}{2}+C_{4}\right) G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+\frac{\varepsilon}{2} G C_{1} \sqrt{|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})| T} \\
& +G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\
\psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\
\psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{2}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}$ defined in (30). Taking $\varepsilon=T^{-\frac{1}{2}}, K=\left\lfloor 2 B T^{\frac{1}{2}}\right\rfloor \leqslant 2 B T$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant 2 C_{3} G \sqrt{\log \left(2 B T\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)} \sqrt{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|T|}+\left(2^{-1} C_{1}+C_{2} 2^{-1} T^{-\frac{1}{2}}+C_{4}\right) G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})| \\
& +G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\
\psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\
\psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{2}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha
\end{array}\right.
\end{aligned}
$$

Since this inequality holds for all pruning $\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$, one can take the infimum over all pruning in $\mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$ to get the desired upper-bound:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant \inf _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)}\left\{\beta_{1} \sqrt{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|T|}+\beta_{2}|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|\right. \\
& +G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\
\psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\
\psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{2}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha
\end{array}\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

with $\beta_{1}=2 C_{3} G \sqrt{\log \left(2 B T\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)}$ and $\beta_{2}=G\left(2^{-1} C_{1}+C_{2} 2^{-1} T^{-\frac{1}{2}}+C_{4}\right)$.

- Case 2: $\left(\ell_{t}\right)_{1 \leqslant t \leqslant T} \eta$-exp-concave.

If the sequence of loss functions $\left(\ell_{t}\right)$ is $\eta$-exp-concave for some $\eta>0$, then thanks to a Lemma in Hazan et al. (2016) we have for any $0<\mu \leqslant \frac{1}{2} \min \left\{\frac{1}{G}, \eta\right\}$ and all $t \geqslant 1, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T}), k \in[K]$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{n, k, t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} & \leqslant\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}-\frac{\mu}{2}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2}\right) \mathbb{1}_{x_{t} \in \mathcal{X}_{n}} \\
& =\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}-\frac{\mu}{2}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2} \quad \leftarrow \text { by (34) }
\end{aligned}
$$

Summing (38) over $t \in[T]$ and $n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1} & \leqslant \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}} \tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \tilde{\mathbf{w}}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}-\frac{\mu}{2} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{P})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2} \\
& \leqslant C_{4} G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+\tilde{C}_{3} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sqrt{\sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2}}-\frac{\mu}{2} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2} \leftarrow \text { by (36) }
\end{aligned}
$$

where we set $\tilde{C}_{3}=C_{3} \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)}$. Young's inequality gives, for any $\nu>0$, the following upper-bound:

$$
\sqrt{\sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2}} \leqslant \frac{1}{2 \nu}+\frac{\nu}{2} \sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2}
$$

Finally, plugging (40) with $\nu=\mu / \tilde{C}_{3}>0$ in (39), we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
R_{1} & \leqslant C_{4} G|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+\tilde{C}_{3} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(\frac{\tilde{C}_{3}}{2 \mu}+\frac{\mu}{2 \tilde{C}_{3}} \sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2}\right)-\frac{\mu}{2} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \sum_{t \in T_{n}}\left(\tilde{\mathbf{g}}_{t}^{\top} \mathbf{w}_{t}-\tilde{g}_{n, k, t}\right)^{2} \\
& =\left(\frac{C_{3}^{2} \log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)}{2 \mu}+C_{4} G\right)|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|
\end{aligned}
$$

To conclude, if $\left(\ell_{t}\right)$ are $\eta$-exp-concave, one has via (25), (30) and (41)

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant \beta_{3}|\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})|+G|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha} \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f) 2^{-\alpha(\mathrm{d}(n)-1)}\left\{\begin{array}{ll}
\psi_{1} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d<2 \alpha \\
\psi_{2} \log _{2}\left|T_{n}\right| \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|} & \text { if } d=2 \alpha \\
\psi_{1}\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{\alpha}{2}} & \text { if } d>2 \alpha
\end{array}\right.
$$

with $\beta_{3}=\frac{C_{3}^{2} \log \left(2 B T\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)}{2 \mu}+C_{4} G+2^{-1} G\left(C_{1}+C_{2} T^{-\frac{1}{2}}\right), 0<\mu<\frac{1}{2} \min \left\{\frac{1}{G}, \eta\right\}$ and $\psi_{1}, \psi_{2}$ defined in (30). Again, taking infimum over $\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$ gives the result.

Worst case regret bound Note that since we assume that $\|f\|_{\infty} \leqslant B$, and that all local predictors $\hat{f}_{n, k}, n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right), k \in[K]$ in Algorithm 2 are clipped in $[-B, B]$, we first have for any $x \in \mathcal{X}$,

$$
\left|\hat{f}_{t}(x)\right|=\sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)} \sum_{k=1}^{K} w_{n, k, t}\left|\hat{f}_{n, k, t}(x)\right| \leqslant B \sum_{n \in \mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)} \sum_{k=1}^{K} w_{n, k, t}=B
$$

Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) & =\sum_{t=1}^{T} \ell_{t}\left(\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right)-\ell_{t}\left(f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right) \\
& \leqslant \sum_{t=1}^{T} G\left|\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)-f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right| \quad \leftarrow \ell_{t} \text { is } G \text {-Lipschitz } \\
& \leqslant G \sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(\left|\hat{f}_{t}\left(x_{t}\right)\right|+\left|f^{*}\left(x_{t}\right)\right|\right) \\
& =2 B G T
\end{aligned}
$$

# Appendix C. Proof of Corollary 1 

We state here a complete version of Corollary 1.
Corollary 2 Let $\alpha \in(0,1], 1 \leqslant d \leqslant 2 \alpha$. Under the same assumptions as in Theorem 2, Algorithm 2 achieves a regret with respect to any $f \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L), L>0$ :

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \lesssim \inf _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)}\left\{\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \min \left(1+L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha},\left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\right)^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha}}\right) \sqrt{T_{n}}\right\}
$$

where $\lesssim$ is a rough inequality that depends on $C_{i}, i=1, \ldots, 4$ but is independent of $L, X, T$. Moreover, if $\left(\ell_{t}\right)$ are exp-concave:

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \lesssim \inf _{\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)}\left\{\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \min \left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|},\left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\right)^{\frac{2}{2 \alpha+1}}\left|T_{n}\right|^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha+1}}\right)\right\}
$$

where $\lesssim$ also depends on the exp-concavity constant.

## Proof [of Corollary 2]

We consider 2 cases:

1. Case $d<2 \alpha$ (i.e. $d=1, \alpha \in\left(\frac{1}{2}, 1\right]$ ).

Let $f \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)$ and $L>0$ and fix any pruning $\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$. We will apply Theorem 2 to an extended pruning $\mathcal{T}^{\prime}$, in which we extend each leaf $n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$ by a regular tree of depth $h_{n} \in \mathbb{N}$ to be optimized later in the proof. In particular, for each leaf $n$ in the original pruning $\mathcal{T}, \mathcal{T}^{\prime}$ has $2^{h_{n}}$ leaves $m$ at depth $\mathrm{d}(m)=\mathrm{d}(n)+h_{n} \geqslant \mathrm{d}(n)$ with $L_{m}(f) \leqslant L_{n}(f)$. In particular, when $h_{n}=0$, the original pruning $\mathcal{T}$ is recovered.
(a) Case $\left(\ell_{t}\right)$ convex:

Thanks to Theorem 2 (without applying Inequality (37) in the term depending on $C_{3}$ ), one has for $d=1<2 \alpha$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant 2 C_{3} \sqrt{\log \left(K\left|\mathcal{N}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)\right|\right)} \sum_{m \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathcal{T}^{\prime}\right)} \sqrt{\left|T_{m}\right|}+C_{4} G\left|\mathcal{L}\left(\mathcal{T}_{1}\right)\right| \\
& +G \psi_{1} \sum_{m \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathcal{T}^{\prime}\right)} L_{m}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{m}\right|^{\alpha} \sqrt{\left|T_{m}\right|}, \\
& \leqslant \min _{h_{n} \in \mathbb{N}}\left\{C \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(\sqrt{2^{h_{n}}\left|T_{n}\right|}+2^{h_{n}}+L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha} 2^{-\alpha h_{n}} \sqrt{2^{h_{n}}\left|T_{n}\right|}\right)\right\}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $C>0$ is some constant that depends on $C_{3}, C_{4}, G, X, \log (T), B$ and $\psi_{1}$ (defined in Theorem 2) but independent of other quantities $L_{n}(f), T, T_{n}$, that is used to simplify the presentation and may change from a display to another along the proof. Then, optimizing over $h_{n}$ so that

$$
\sqrt{2^{h_{n}\left|T_{n}\right|}}=L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha} 2^{-\alpha h_{n}} \sqrt{2^{h_{n}}\left|T_{n}\right|}
$$

we set

$$
h_{n}=\max \left\{0, \frac{1}{\alpha} \log _{2}\left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\right)\right\} \geqslant 0
$$

which yields

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant C \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \min \left\{1+L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha},\left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\right)^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha}}\right\} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|}
$$

(b) Case $\left(\ell_{t}\right)$ exp-concave:

Since $\left(\ell_{t}\right)$ are exp-concave, Theorem 2 (with Inequality (41)) gives, for $d<2 \alpha$, for any extension $\mathcal{T}_{1}$ of pruning $\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) & \leqslant C\left(\left|\mathcal{L}\left(\mathcal{T}_{1}\right)\right|+\sum_{m \in \mathcal{L}\left(\mathcal{T}_{1}\right)} L_{m}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{m}\right|^{\alpha} \sqrt{\left|T_{m}\right|}\right) \\
& \leqslant C \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(2^{h_{n}}+L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha} 2^{-\alpha h_{n}} \sqrt{2^{h_{n}}\left|T_{n}\right|}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where again $C>0$ is a constant independent of $L, L_{n}(f),\left|T_{n}\right|$ and $h_{n}$ that may change from a display to another. Optimizing over $h_{n}$ by equalizing the terms:

$$
2^{h_{n}}=L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha} 2^{-\alpha h_{n}} \sqrt{2^{h_{n}}\left|T_{n}\right|}
$$

leads to

$$
h_{n}=\max \left\{0, \frac{2}{2 \alpha+1} \log _{2}\left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\left|T_{n}\right|^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)\right\}
$$

which yields and concludes the proof:

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \leqslant C \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} \min \left\{L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha} \sqrt{\left|T_{n}\right|},\left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\right)^{\frac{2}{2 \alpha+1}}\left|T_{n}\right|^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha+1}}\right\}
$$

2. Case $d=2 \alpha$.

The proof is the same as for the case $d<2 \alpha$ but with $C$ now depending on $\psi_{2}$ (also defined in Theorem 1) rather than $\psi_{1}$. We get the same result.

# Appendix D. Proof of Equation (9) 

One has, for any pruning $\mathcal{T} \in \mathcal{P}\left(\mathcal{T}_{0}\right)$ and some $f \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)$ :

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \lesssim \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(L_{n}(f)\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|^{\alpha}\right)^{\frac{2}{2 \alpha+1}}\left|T_{n}\right|^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha+1}} & =\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})}\left(L_{n}(f)^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|\right)^{\frac{2 \alpha}{2 \alpha+1}}\left|T_{n}\right|^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha+1}} \\
& \leqslant\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f)^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|\right)^{\frac{2 \alpha}{2 \alpha+1}}\left|\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} T_{n}\right|^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha+1}} \\
& =\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f)^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|\right)^{\frac{2 \alpha}{2 \alpha+1}}|T|^{\frac{1}{2 \alpha+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where inequality is obtained with Hölder's inequality with $p=(2 \alpha+1) / 2 \alpha$ and $q=2 \alpha+1$.
One could also write:

$$
\left(\sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f)^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|\right)^{\frac{2 \alpha}{2 \alpha+1}}=\left(|\mathcal{X}| \sum_{n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})} L_{n}(f)^{\frac{1}{\alpha}} \frac{\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right|}{|\mathcal{X}|}\right)^{\frac{2 \alpha}{2 \alpha+1}}:=\left(|\mathcal{X}|^{\alpha}\|f\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T}), \frac{1}{\alpha}}\right)^{\frac{2}{2 \alpha+1}}
$$

where $f \mapsto\|f\|_{\mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T}), \frac{1}{\alpha}}$ is some $\frac{1}{\alpha}$-norm (or expectation) of $f$ over leaves $n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$ with probability $\left|\mathcal{X}_{n}\right| /|\mathcal{X}|=2^{-d(n)}, n \in \mathcal{L}(\mathcal{T})$.

# Appendix F. Experiments 

The following presents experimental results in a synthetic regression setting for both the Chaining Tree method (Algorithm 1) and the Locally Adaptive Online Regression (Algorithm 2. We consider the model $y_{t}=f\left(x_{t}\right)+\varepsilon_{t}$, where $\varepsilon_{t} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0, \sigma^{2}\right)$ with $\sigma=0.5, f(x)=\sin (10 x)+\cos (5 x)+5$, for $x \in \mathcal{X}=[0,1]$ and $\sup _{x}\left|f^{\prime}(x)\right| \leqslant 15=: L$. Furthermore, we assume that $x_{t}$ is independently drawn from the uniform distribution $\mathcal{U}(\mathcal{X})$.
Refer to Theorem 1, Theorem 2 and Corollary 1 in the paper to compare experimental results to theoretical guarantees. Figures can be reproduced using the code available on GitHub.
Key observations:

- For the squared loss, $\ell_{t}(\hat{y})=\left(\hat{y}-y_{t}\right)^{2}$, Algorithm 2 achieves a time rate of $O\left(T^{\frac{1}{3}}\right)$ compared to $O(\sqrt{T})$ for Algorithm 1 - see Figure 4(a). However, the trade-off is an increased dependence on the smoothness $L$, shifting from $O\left(L^{\frac{1}{2}}\right)$ to $O\left(L^{\frac{2}{3}}\right)$;
- We observe in Figure 5 that Algorithm 2 reduces regret with respect to $L$ : it achieves $O(\sqrt{L})$ for absolute loss in Fig. 5(b) and $O\left(L^{\frac{2}{3}}\right)$ for square loss in Fig. 5(a);
- In Figure 5(a) and Figure 5(b), we observe that both the experimental and theoretical curves level off once $L$ increases beyond a certain threshold $L_{0} \gtrsim B T$. Indeed, we demonstrated that for any $f \in \mathscr{C}^{\alpha}(\mathcal{X}, L)$,

$$
\operatorname{Reg}_{T}(f) \lesssim \min \left\{B T, \sum_{n} L_{n}(f)\left|T_{n}\right|^{1-\frac{1}{2}}\right\}
$$

See Appendix B and Equation (42) for more details.
![img-3.jpeg](img-3.jpeg)

Figure 4: Comparison of regret as a function of $T$ for square and absolute loss functions. The dotted lines represent the theoretical results (where $O$ hides terms in $\log T$ ), while the solid lines show the actual performance of our algorithms (mean $\pm$ std over 5 runs).

![img-4.jpeg](img-4.jpeg)

Figure 5: Regret (mean $\pm$ std over 5 runs) as a function of $L$ for square and absolute loss functions, with a fixed horizon of $T=2000$. The analysis uses 20 equally spaced constants $l \in$ $\left[2^{-6}, 2^{5}\right]$, which define the different Lipschitz functions where we apply our algorithms, given by $f_{l}(x)=f(l x)$ such that $\sup _{x \in \mathcal{X}}\left|f_{l}^{\prime}(x)\right| \leqslant 15 l=: L$.
![img-5.jpeg](img-5.jpeg)

Figure 6: Predictions for Chaining Tree (Alg. 1) and Locally Adaptive Online Regression (Alg. 2) after $T=1000$ data. For illustration purposes, we set the depth of the Chaining Trees to 5 and that of the Core Tree to 3 .
Note: A minor adjustment has been made to the implementation of the Locally Adaptive Online Regression algorithm (Alg. 2). Rather than performing a grid search to determine the root nodes of the CT in Core Tree $\mathcal{T}_{0}$, we employ a Follow the Leader (or best expert) strategy. For squared losses, this method offers a similar benefit, that is reducing the regret for learning the root nodes from $O(B \sqrt{T})$ to $O(B \log (T))$ - see Cesa-Bianchi and Lugosi (2006, Chap 3.2). Consequently, the overall performance bound is improved, especially in low-dimensional cases (see Corollary 1, exp-concave case).

abstract:
We study adversarial online nonparametric regression with general convex
losses and propose a parameter-free learning algorithm that achieves minimax
optimal rates. Our approach leverages chaining trees to compete against
H{\"o}lder functions and establishes optimal regret bounds. While competing
with nonparametric function classes can be challenging, they often exhibit
local patterns - such as local H{\"o}lder continuity - that online algorithms
can exploit. Without prior knowledge, our method dynamically tracks and adapts
to different H{\"o}lder profiles by pruning a core chaining tree structure,
aligning itself with local smoothness variations. This leads to the first
computationally efficient algorithm with locally adaptive optimal rates for
online regression in an adversarial setting. Finally, we discuss how these
notions could be extended to a boosting framework, offering promising
directions for future research.
